channel.title: How I save money (and it works!)
channel.description: Steve Dempsey has been a frugal spender for many years and he wants to pass this knowledge on to you.

image.title: How I save money (and it works!)

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: sdempsey123
item.content:encoded: Now that you've seen some of my tips on how to save money, perhaps you have some ideas of your own or maybe you want to simply comment on the way I shop. Make your observations in the comments section below here.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I want to invite our users to share their experiences on the best ways to save money.

item.title: Groceries
item.dc:creator: sdempsey123
item.content:encoded:
Here is an example of what you'll see when you use the Safeway app

Keep your eyes open

If I had to pick the best area to save money, going to the grocery store is at the top of the list. It's obvious. We need groceries on a daily or weekly basis. We have to eat. We have to drink. Grocery stores carry some great deals. I understand that, at this time, supplies can be dicey and prices are going up. One store we went to had no cat food -- try explaining that to your feline friend. That makes strategic shopping even more important.
This takes some planning and trips to different stores. Your friend here is the store's app but this varies from store-to-store.  I like the Safeway app. It's easy to find things you're looking for and the discounts are pretty good. I don't really use apps with other stores such as Lucky's and Raley's in Northern California, but I go on their sites and select weekly ad, and some great deals will pop up. It generally changes each Wednesday. If you're not a digital type of person, those Wednesday print ads can certainly come through.
My personal favorite is Grocery Outlet although there are a couple of things you should know. First, its weekly ad is small and basically no good.  Ditto for the website. The savings, however, can be really good if you find what you need or what you may need in the near future. The bad news is you'll see something one week and the same item is gone the next week. Still, when we do our weekly shopping, Grocery Outlet is where we start.
Keep in mind that I don't have the time or space to be someone who clips hundreds of coupons each week and get these incredible deals. This advice is meant for the average shopper who can get modest savings on a weekly basis.

SAVE WITH CARS

item.title: Spend less
item.dc:creator: sdempsey123
item.content:encoded:
I have been a frugal consumer for many years and, believe me, it has paid off. Maybe you're not familiar with the term frugal, but among its meanings, being frugal means sparing or economical with regard to money or food. That's me. I'm not a person who has made a lot of money over the years. So I try to maximize what little budget I have because every dollar counts. 
I began a routine to find the best deals. That is everything from getting breaks on my bills to shopping at the grocery store. It seems like a lot of work but if you can get a routine down, it pays off. When you save a little here, and a little there, it really adds up.
FULL DISCLOSURE: This website covers how I find good savings and should be taken as advice based on what works for me. It's kind of like Black Friday every day. Go to my contact page to make comments and, perhaps, you can advise us on ways to save money.

Here are some examples of good savings:

  • Outlets like Xfinity will deal with you if you talk to a live person. Just ask something like "do you have any specials that are close to my current plan?" Pretty much every time someone will find something that works. 
  • Places like Best Buy have what is known as open-box electronics where you get a huge discount on items. I did that with a new washer and dryer, and a 24-inch monitor. I saved hundreds of dollars.

READ MORE

item.title: Cars
item.dc:creator: sdempsey123
item.content:encoded:
Take your time

For drivers, taking care of your cars can be the biggest challenge toward maintaining a frugal budget. I'm talking about the normal maintenance and not anything major. The cost of gas and oil changes continues to soar, but you do have some control as to how much you spend to keep your car properly maintained.
Let's start with gas. Yep, at least in California, prices have reached $5 per gallon with no end in sight. What I started to do a long time ago is to drive around to find great prices. You won't see that with stations such as Chevron or Shell, but I suggest cheaper places like Rotten Robbie, Safeway or even other independents. There is also AM/PM but you have to pay cash to get the good discount. Believe me, this is where you can save in the range of 50 cents a gallon, and that adds up.
In addition to saving money at the pump directly, changing your driving habits can go a long way. What I do on the freeway is to put my car on cruise control at about 65-70 mph (or higher depending on the speed limit) and cut down on my lane changes. Around town, don't speed or race from the start. Also, keep your tires properly inflated. You will notice a change in gas mileage.
Oil changes have really gone up in price especially if your car needs synthetic oil (as most of your newer cars use). With that, finding the right oil change near me becomes a big challenge to cut cost. Some oil changes could go for nearly $200 now, but you don't have to do that. Do some homework with ads or online specials and find some independent outlets that do cheaper oil changes through ads. I recently discovered Walmart has some good deals at its automotive outlets.

SAVE WITH CLOTHES

item.title: Clothes
item.dc:creator: sdempsey123
item.content:encoded:
Finding the best deals

Shopping for clothes and shoes can be very profitable if you play your cards right. The selections are huge and there is so much to choose from. The holiday season can produce sales all over the place from online to retail outlets, but my methods can be used anytime during the year.

If I'm looking for clothes and shoes, I pretty much stay away from the malls. Those prices are pretty expensive for my taste. However, you can pretty much count on stores like Kohl's to have reasonable prices (and great discounts with Kohl's cash). I like stores such as Ross or Marshall's because you can save as much as 50 percent to the major retailers. I even include Goodwill on my shopping list because the quality of merchandise has risen, and I believe this is worth at least a visit because you never know what you might find.

Now, don't get me wrong. There are some outstanding buys online with no shipping cost to you. That sounds good, but online shopping for clothes can be tricky. You order a shirt that's extra large, but when you get it, it's too small, or vice versa, the extra large is like a big potato sack. Shoe shopping online is just as dicey. The size 8 shoe is really size 7 to another online retailer. I agree that online shopping is the way to go for many items, but I stay away from clothes and shoes online shopping.

SAVE WITH RECREATION

item.title: Recreation
item.dc:creator: sdempsey123
item.content:encoded:
Find ways to lower cost

If you like to lead a healthy lifestyle, this could be a pretty expensive venture. Buying equipment for your favorite form of exercise can cost even into the thousands. Think about it, do you need state of the art exercise equipment or a new set for golf clubs for $1,200 or more? Probably not.
There are ways to getting around this without breaking the bank. When it comes to exercise equipment, I do plenty of things for my workouts that don't include a lot of equipment. In fact, all I need are a small pair of weights and a whole lot of crunches. But, maybe you need something else. In this case, I suggest going online and check out Amazon with its wide array of equipment. If you don't trust going online for your equipment, see if you have discount retailers like Play It Again Sports, which has a good stock of used exercise equipment or bicycles.
Now, I am a golfer -- not very good, but I do chase the white ball around a course for a time or two. Golf is one sport that can be very expensive. For me, I began with a set of used clubs I got from a friend and went from there. As I progressed, I looked for better quality at a good price. Golf Galaxy and Golf Mart have some great deals for quality used clubs. I saved hundreds with clubs and a golf bag ($220 retail, I bought for $40). As far as golfing, you also have to consider green fees. It can be expensive. Try looking for cheap golf courses in your area. A good way to do that is with GolfNow that checks courses near where you live and you find the best deals. I can't tell you how much I have saved thanks to GolfNow.
However, you can save a lot of money and pick up a cheap pair of running or walking shoes either online or outlets like Big 5 Sporting Goods, which has a good selection of reasonably-priced shoes. Then, go for a run or a walk. Great exercise, good satisfaction for you, and no worries about cost.

MAKE COMMENTS
